content.description: Fun little line that has an obvious start with the slots in the horizontal crack that is maybe hip high or so. Move up to the rail and then start navigating squeezing both aretes. The rock is gritty, so that's awesome, but getting the feet up is the main challenge.
content.protection: Couple of pads. Landing is so-so and a spotter would be handy.
content.location: Lower band, further up stream from "morning slug" and other lines. If you hit the bigger wall that looks a bit chossy, you're barely too far and will see it you turn around.

content.description:
Fun little traverse line. Start way left and go all the way till you hit the crack system heading up towards a smallish tree. I didn't clean the top of the line as it would require a ton of clearing of dirt/etc and it's simply not worth it to do that much cleaning just to top this out, especially since the traverse aspect is really what this line is all about.

 Side note, the landing under it has seen some erosion over the last year and could use some love to make it more user friendly.
content.location: Head down towards the lower cliff band and then turn around to walk to the creek. You'll see it on your right side once at the creek. Start and finish of the line is very easy to see.

content.description: SDS with hand jamming in huge feature and other hand on left arete. Make your way up to big hold on the face and then hop to the top.
Another project line that needs to be sent. Get after it.Start way left on the face on obvious jug hold and traverse right and up using some sweet sidepulls, crimps, and an amazing undercling.

Super fun line following the arching arete. Sit start with both hands on big hold and move up to using sloping features on the arete and some so-so feet on the face. The top is where the business is located.
content.protection: Several pads and a spotter, landing is downhill style, surfs up!
content.location: Pretty obvious, just look at the pics...

content.description: Located on the upper band, you will see this one right away. There's a tree right at it, but is easy to avoid the dab. Sit start with left hand on longish rail and right hand on large pinch thing coming out of the wall. High right foot will let you rock up and get into the crack that will lead up and to the left. An easier start is right hand on the longish rail and left hand on super nice sidepull in other crack.
content.location: Look for the tree on the upper wall, very easy to find.

content.description: Sit start with left hand on undercling and right on crimp. Move up to another crimp or straight into big hold in dihedral. Climb up and out the mini roof. Several ways to finish it, but the direct up the face without using the huge crack off to the right is the most fun.
content.location: Lower cliff band, pretty much the first boulder you'll run into once you go down there. Hard to miss the unique roof feature.

content.description: Pretty basic line that leads up the small crack. This is the first line you will hit when walking in, on the upper cliff band. SDS with 2 sidepulls and move on up using other sidepull holds. Really good positive holds and the top in the tricky part requiring some fancy footwork and a mantle.
content.protection: Couple of pads, landing in sloping downhill.

content.description: Clean, fun line on good rock. Start on the starting holds for the v6  then head up and right, following the crack. The top out is relatively easy but a fall would be awkward and could be somewhat dangerous if there isn't enough pads.
content.location: On the lower cliff band to the right of the v6.

content.description: SDS with undercling/sidepull to the right of the arete and work up the crack holds and to the left into the face leading into the flaring crack that will take you to the top. Once topping out you will trend to the right to use the same finish at the V1 next to it. A straight up finish might be possible, but would up the sketch factor quite a bit.

Another local spot located right in town, this time in Lincoln Park. This spot has a handful of fun lines up so far, but room for several more lines. There's a nice little creek in the area and lots of Ferns (hence the name), so it makes for a pretty nice little spot to get some moves in.
